policy_name = self.table.kwargs['policy_name'] return reverse(self.url, args=(policy_name,)) class DeleteRule(policy.PolicyTargetMixin, tables.DeleteAction): @staticmethod def action_present(count): return ungettext_lazy( u'Delete Rule', u'Delete Rules', count ) @staticmethod def action_past(count): return ungettext_lazy( u'Deleted rule', u'Deleted rules', count ) redirect_url = 'horizon:admin:policies:detail' def delete(self, request, obj_id): policy_name = self.table.kwargs['policy_name'] LOG.info('User %s deleting policy "%s" rule "%s" in tenant %s', request.user.username, policy_name, obj_id, request.user.tenant_name) try: congress.policy_rule_delete(request, policy_name, obj_id) LOG.info('Deleted policy rule "%s"', obj_id) except Exception as e: msg_args = {'rule_id': obj_id, 'error': str(e)} msg = _('Failed to delete policy rule "%(rule_id)s": ' '%(error)s') % msg_args LOG.error(msg) messages.error(request, msg) redirect = reverse(self.redirect_url, args=(policy_name,)) raise exceptions.Http302(redirect) def _format_rule(rule): """Make rule's text more human readable.""" head_body = rule.split(congress.RULE_SEPARATOR) if len(head_body) < 2: return rule head = head_body[0] body = head_body[1] # Add newline after each literal in the body. body_literals = body.split(congress.LITERALS_SEPARATOR) literals_break = congress.LITERALS_SEPARATOR + '\n' new_body = literals_break.join(body_literals) # Add newline after the head. rules_break = congress.RULE_SEPARATOR + '\n' return rules_break.join([head, new_body]) class PolicyRulesTable(tables.DataTable): id = tables.Column("id", verbose_name=_("Rule ID")) name = tables.Column("name", verbose_name=_("Name")) comment = tables.Column("comment", verbose_name=_("Comment")) rule = tables.Column("rule", verbose_name=_("Rule"), filters=(_format_rule, linebreaksbr,)) class Meta(object): name = "policy_rules" verbose_name = _("Rules") table_actions = (CreateRule, DeleteRule,) row_actions = (DeleteRule,) hidden_title = False def get_policy_table_link(datum): return reverse('horizon:admin:policies:policy_table_detail', args=(datum['policy_name'], datum['name'])) class PoliciesTablesTable(tables.DataTable): name = tables.Column("name", verbose_name=_("Table Name"), link=get_policy_table_link) class Meta(object): name = "policies_tables" commit_message:
Add TLS for ec2api metadata service

This adds a TLS proxy in front of it so it serves TLS in the
internal network.

bp tls-via-certmonger

commit_message:
config-download: use workflow supported in Queens

In Queens, tripleoclient will run a Mistral workflow to execute the
ansible tasks.
See I18815c9920454290d965ef632a29ee13c718cd0d and
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/514701/ for details.

This patch does:

- adding some notes in comments so we cleanup later

Note: a lot of this work will be cleaned up later as we're doing fast
iterations here.

Change-Id: If23e223b4a0387efcc745d02154c6bdd2dee23fc
Implements: ansible-config-download-ci
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-quickstart-extras refs/changes/41/516841/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - when: deploy_steps_ansible|bool block: - name: Add subnodes to known hosts shell: | ssh-keyscan 192.168.24.3 >> ~/.ssh/known_hosts
deleted_lines: - when: step_tripleo_config_download|bool block: # The config-download workflow is temporary until we have a Mistral workflow, # then we won't need these steps. - name: Cleanup TripleO configuration file: path: "{{ working_dir }}/tripleo-config-download" state: absent - name: Download TripleO configuration shell: > set -o pipefail && source {{ working_dir }}/stackrc && tripleo-config-download 2>&1 {{ timestamper_cmd }} > {{ tripleo_config_download_log }} - when: deploy_steps_ansible|bool block: - name: Add subnodes to known hosts shell: | ssh-keyscan 192.168.24.3 >> ~/.ssh/known_hosts - name: Deploy steps with Ansible shell: > set -o pipefail && source {{ working_dir }}/stackrc && tripleo-ansible-inventory --ansible_ssh_user $(whoami) --static-inventory {{ working_dir }}/inventory && ansible-playbook -i {{ working_dir }}/inventory {{ working_dir }}/tripleo-config-download/tripleo-*-config/deploy_steps_playbook.yaml 2>&1 {{ timestamper_cmd }} > {{ ansible_steps_log }} environment: ANSIBLE_SSH_ARGS: ""

Pin fluent-plugin-grok-parser to 2.1.4

We are using upstream fluentd, which has bump to 0.14.0. Need use high
version of plugin.

commit_message:
Remove neutron debug tool

Commit 1f4c82ce9ea0676c4e813cc34bdb8687f63452e3 marked the code as
deprecated. This is over 18 months ago and no one uses this.

This patch finally removes the code.

Change-Id: Id79a18b6fa977f654d5799b8e91ce3f5f7274728

commit_message:
Support Token Session in Zaqar

Token Session: the basic idea is Zaqar
can support to verify the token with keytone once,
and keep this token valid for a while that means no
need to verity the token again.

This purpose is to enhance the Zaqar's performace,
reduce the time spent on keystone authorization.

Change-Id: I5a5a480a8cdfbb32d3d6267cb7dc441f3bf5a6f4
Implements: blueprint support-token-session-in-zaqar
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/zaqar-specs refs/changes/05/519005/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
TrivialFix: Doc format error in configuration/configuring.rst

License info should be not generated in the output html files,
But previous doc has output the license info in configure doc,
this is to fix that.

commit_message:
Fix: magnum devstack installation with tls-proxy

Fix wrongly used start_tls_proxy function and correctly set api port
when tls-proxy is enabled.

Also remove start_tls_proxy for ec2 which is not required.

Co-Authored-By: yatin <ykarel@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I71b85b5cb018dd790e13aaa1eeefcbb8ac0b3b85
Closes-Bug: #1727613

commit_message:
Tolerate spaces in extra capability values

The intent behind limiting the split of the query string at all appears
to be supporting values with spaces, but it's off-by-one, limiting the
number of splits to 3 (4 parts max) rather than 3 parts max.

This commit also generates new random values for variables id and
computehost_id during each call to _get_fake_host_extra_capabilities()
rather than just once, which is necessary to avoid a failing test due to
duplicate id values.

Closes-Bug: #1732787
Change-Id: I8dc56aa983ca27763a63325810753148cb8d8ecd

commit_message:
Allow deleting leases which failed to start at any time

Leases which failed to start could not be deleted until their end date.
This patch enables deletion of such leases at any time.

Change-Id: I8a4764fdcf4750a0dd89e787ee96d930245e8cf7
Closes-Bug: #1713768
(cherry picked from commit 3c1143085fa38a4e31b06d3c798586caf47dc27c)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/blazar refs/changes/37/519637/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_delete_lease_after_starting_date_with_error_status(self): def fake_event_get(sort_key, sort_dir, filters): if filters['event_type'] == 'start_lease': return {'id': 'fake', 'status': 'ERROR'} elif filters['event_type'] == 'end_lease': return {'id': 'fake', 'status': 'UNDONE'} else: return None event_get = self.patch(db_api, 'event_get_first_sorted_by_filters') event_get.side_effect = fake_event_get fake_get_lease = self.patch(self.manager, 'get_lease') fake_get_lease.return_value = self.lease target = datetime.datetime(2013, 12, 20, 13, 30) with mock.patch.object(datetime, 'datetime', mock.Mock(wraps=datetime.datetime)) as patched: patched.utcnow.return_value = target self.manager.delete_lease(self.lease_id) self.event_update.assert_called_once_with('fake', {'status': 'IN_PROGRESS'}) self.fake_plugin.on_end.assert_called_with('111') self.lease_destroy.assert_called_once_with(self.lease_id)

commit_message:
Spec: monitor states of resources

Partially Implements: blueprint resource-monitoring

Change-Id: I5a6b87910636bb476b94f68caaf74da83dafb987
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/blazar refs/changes/51/506551/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =========================== Monitor states of resources =========================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/blazar/+spec/resource-monitoring States of leased/reserved resources are not tracked currently. This spec proposes a new feature that monitors the states of leased/reserved resources and heals the lease from failure conditions. Problem description =================== A lease owner cannot use leased resources if the resources go down, even though the lease was successfully created. To make matters worse, the lease owner cannot even notice such a failure condition from the lease status because Blazar does not track states of leased/reserved resources. Use Cases --------- * Lease owners expects leased resources are available if the status of the lease is fine. * Admins who have a privilege of resource operations, e.g. CRUD for /v1/hosts, expects Blazar to notify them about failures of resources in the pool. Proposed change =============== Overview -------- Blazar monitors the states of resources, and heals damaged leases. Monitor states of resources ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ Have the blazar-manager monitor states of resources. At least one of following two types of monitoring feature should be supported for each resource plugin. 1. Push-based monitoring The blazar-manager listens notification messages sent by other components, e.g. sent by Nova for the host/instance plugins. And it picks up messages which refer to the resources managed by Blazar, i.e. a record of the resource is stored in the Blazar database. A publisher ID and topics to subscribe are provided by each resource plugin. 2. Polling-based monitoring The blazar-manger periodically calls a states check method of each resource plugin. Then, the resource plugin checks states of resources, e.g. *List Hypervisors* of the Compute API is used for the host/instance plugins. If any failure is detected, it is notified to the blazar-manager. The blazar-manager starts monitoring after loading resource plugins. A type of monitoring feature is configurable for each resource plugin. Update states of resources ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ If any failure is detected, the blazar-manager calls the resurce plugin to handle it. Then, for the first, the resource plugin updates the field named *available* in the record of the failure resource to *FALSE*. The record here means the record stored in the resource table of the Blazar database, e.g. the record of the computehosts table for the host/instance plugins. Even though the computehosts table has a field named *status*, we do not use this field because it leads to misunderstanding that the *status* field copies the status of the hypervisor in Nova. Instead, we introduce a new boolean field named *available* which is decided by the combination of the state and the status of the hypervisor in Nova. Only if the state is *up* and the status is *enabled*, the *available* field becomes *TRUE*. i.e. it becomes *FALSE* if the state becomes *down* or the status becomes *disabled*. Heal damaged leases ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ After updating the status (= *available* field) of the failure resource, the resource plugin discovers leases which suffer from the failure, and tries to heal the leases. In the healing process, for the first, the resource plugin looks for available resources which satisfy requirements of the lease. Then, it take following actions: * Case 1. Lease is not started yet * Case 1-1. Enough resources are available Reserve new resources instead of failure resources. States of the lease and reservations included in the lease are not changed. * Case 1-2. Alternative resource is not available Mark the lease as *DEGRADED*, i.e. change the lease status to *\*-DEGRADED*, and change the reservation status to *MISSING_RESOURCES*. * Case 2. Lease has been already started * Case 2-1. Enough resources are available: Lease new resources instead of failure resources. And change the lease status to *\*-DEGRADED* and the reservation status to *RESOURCES_CHANGED*. * Case 1-2. Alternative resource is not available Change the lease status to *\*-DEGRADED* and the reservation status to *MISSING_RESOURCES*. From the architectural view, resource-dependent tables like the computehosts, computehost_allocations, computehost_reservations and instance_reservations tables are updated by the resource plugin. General tables like leases and reservations tables are updated by the manager. Notifications ^^^^^^^^^^^^^ The blazar-mangaer publishes notifications if states of leases, reservations or resources are changed. Alternatives ------------ Other monitoring services like Monasca can be used instead. However, it is not a good solution in terms of cross-components dependency. Dependency should be reduced as much as possible. Data model impact ----------------- * The leases table: possible values of the *status* field increases because new states *\*-DEGRADED* are introduced. Complete set of the states will be defined by the state-machine blueprint [1]. * The reservations table: possible values of the *status* field increases because new states *MISSING_RESOURCES* and *RESOURCES_CHANGED* are introduced. Complete set of the states will be defined by the state-machine blueprint [1]. * The computehosts table: the *status* filed will be removed because it is never used. Introduce a new boolean field *available* instead. REST API impact --------------- * With the data model changes described above, some fields included in the REST API response body will be changed a little. Security impact --------------- None. Notifications impact -------------------- The blazar-manager sends following two new notifications. * Lease status change: notifies changes of the status of lease and reservations included in the lease. * Resource status change: notifies the change of the status of the resource which is managed by Blazar. i.e. Notifies the change of the *available* field of the records in the resource table of the Blazar database. Other end user impact --------------------- * States of leases and reservations will be changed. Performance Impact ------------------ None. Other deployer impact --------------------- * New configuration options related to the monitoring feature like a type of monitoring, publisher ID and topics to subscribe will be added for each resource plugin. Developer impact ---------------- All resource plugins (including new plugins supported in the future) have to support at least one type of resource monitoring feature. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: hiro-kobayashi Work Items ---------- 1. Define complete set of states of a lease and a reservation. This will be done by the state-machine blueprint[1]. 2. Implement the monitoring mechanism into the blazar-manager. 3. Change the schema of the computehosts table. Concretely, remove the *status* field and add a new *available* field. 4. Change resource look-up features, e.g. _matching_hosts() method for the host plugin and the pickup_hosts() method for the instance plugin, to care the *available* field of the record in the computehosts table. 5. Implement a resource specific monitoring feature called by the blazar-manager into each resource plugin. Focus on a push-based monitoring feature of the host plugin for the first. 6. Implement the lease-healing feature into each resource plugin. 7. Implement the notifications feature. 8. Change the devstack setup script to enable the monitoring feature 9. Write a user guide Dependencies ============ * Possible states of a lease and a reservation depend on the state-machine blueprint[1]. Testing ======= * Test the monitoring feature. * Test the lease-healing feature. Documentation Impact ==================== * This new feature should be described in the introduction document. * The installation guide will be updated to mention how to setup the monitoring feature. * API references will be updated because the response body will be changed a little. References ========== * [1] state-machine blueprint <https://blueprints.launchpad.net/blazar/+spec/state-machine> * [2] Discussion at the Denver PTG <https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/blazar-resource-monitoring> History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Queens - Introduced

subject: Fix display of host details when cpu_info is empty
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-11-14 16:03:34.000000000', 'files': ['blazar_dashboard/api/client.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/blazar-dashboard/commit/8066409cdad0e026d2b14130f54bd55c2e3ad181', 'message': 'Fix display of host details when cpu_info is empty

If a Blazar host was created with an empty cpu_info value, displaying
host details would fail with the error:

    SyntaxError: unexpected EOF while parsing (<string>, line 0)

This is because calling eval() on an empty string raises a SyntaxError.
This patch ensures that if cpu_info is empty, it is set to an empty
dictionary instead.

Change-Id: I38d9f92fd7937de4ec1492d06ddea834b6c423ef
'}]
commit_message:
Fix display of host details when cpu_info is empty

If a Blazar host was created with an empty cpu_info value, displaying
host details would fail with the error:

    SyntaxError: unexpected EOF while parsing (<string>, line 0)

This is because calling eval() on an empty string raises a SyntaxError.
This patch ensures that if cpu_info is empty, it is set to an empty
dictionary instead.

Change-Id: I38d9f92fd7937de4ec1492d06ddea834b6c423ef
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/blazar-dashboard refs/changes/90/519690/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: cpu_info_dict = getattr(self, 'cpu_info', '{}') if not cpu_info_dict: cpu_info_dict = '{}' return eval(cpu_info_dict)

commit_message:
Migrate to Zuul v3

Migrate all functional jobs and gate to zuul v3.
We will have to migrate all other legacy jobs too later.
This patch do step 1 in the docs: Move Legacy Jobs to Projects.

Co-Authored-By: Dai Dang Van <daidv@vn.fujitsu.com>

Needed-By: I8e093bd3bb880b6b2c11a20e785c5a562f66159c

Switch to ceph luminous

Tweak override file to install ceph repository from
centos-release-ceph-luminous until Kolla also switch to luminous.

commit_message:
always declare partitioning variables

also, just use partition_coordinator to figure out if we need to handle
stuff as that's what we use everywhere else.

Change-Id: I8724a41408b89f29b600a03fbf1c7febb55fb5e5

revisions:

The upgrade of Ceph to Luminous requires a new daemon, ceph-mgr, to be

commit_message:
Deploy Ceph Luminous and add support for CephMgr service

The upgrade of Ceph to Luminous requires a new daemon, ceph-mgr, to be
deployed with every ceph-mon. This submission adds support for the
deployment of ceph-mgr via ceph-ansible.

Change-Id: I4226233d02b70980c6b53518ae2d511b653ce2de
Depends-On: I3645c6c3f68fcefc93fa8699796ba8892aa946c8
Implements: blueprint ceph-luminous

commit_message:
Remove v1 api-ref documents

This commit removes v1 api-ref documents. Because it's very confusing
when people click the "Block Storage API V1 (LEGACY)" links on the
api-ref page[1]. It's just a link to the api-ref object-storage page[1].

[1] https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/block-storage/index.html

Change-Id: Ibb19bc1b951298c3f95bca7d123d3b7c9dc6b91c

commit_message:
use agent api def from neutron-lib

The agent extension's API definition was moved into neutron-lib with
commit Iae4746aa2e3f68a7120696a12a6ae717115dbc31 and will be consumed
in neutron with I18aebec1e2b5b361d9b96192d4a59e5424c6a80b
This patch consumes it by:
- Switching over to lib's implementation for the agent extension.
- Removing the unit test setup that updates the global
RESOURCE_ATTRIBUTE_MAP for the agent. This is done automatically so
is not needed.

Change-Id: Icd545a57835f7c3a79b82cfffd1b6a6ca017fb0b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lbaas refs/changes/57/520157/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Pluggable drivers for oslo.config

Provide an interface to implement external config readers.

Change-Id: I9833f16088289147f38ea0dd03b2ba56106aa9b5
Co-Authorized-By: Emilien Macchi <emilien@redhat.com>
Implements: blueprint oslo-config-db
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-specs refs/changes/97/454897/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ============================== Pluggable CMDB for oslo.config ============================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/oslo.config/+spec/oslo-config-db Currently, oslo.config is tightly bound to the plain text configuration files. This spec describes changes to allow deployers to store configuration data in a Configuration Management Database (CMDB) such as etcd. Problem description =================== Centralized configuration management is a highly desired feature as it allows having a single point of control of all the configuration parameters for OpenStack components. However, the existing implementation of oslo.config does not support an option to retrieve OpenStack configuration from any backends except INI files on the local file system. Proposed change =============== Update oslo.config so that multiple database backends can be used. Turn the existing INI parser into one driver. Implement an etcd driver as a new driver. The ``--config-file`` command line option is changed to ``--config-url``, with the old option name retained as a deprecated version. The scheme portion of the URL is used to determine which driver to use. The URL components other than the scheme are left up to the driver to define and document. All connection parameters for the driver, including unique identifiers for the host or service (if needed), must be part of the URL. URLs passed to ``--config-url`` without a scheme are treated as though the scheme is "file", and parsed using the existing INI parser. Each occurance of ``--config-url`` adds a new "source" to the end of a search path. When ConfigOpt looks for an option, it goes through the sources in the order they are provided, starting with the command line options and then the sources provided by the user. The first source that provides a configured value for an option causes the search to end (sources are not "merged"). An occurance of ``--config-dir`` will continue to be treated as a single source, as it is now (all of the options are merged into one namespace) using the INI file driver. Supporting multiple URLs allows a deployer to pass a host-specific URL and then a site-specific URL, reducing the number of places that common configuration values need to be synchronized. This is optional, though, so simple deployments can use a single URL for each service instance. In production use, we expect to see two operating modes. Containerized deployments are most likely to pass one or more URLs to the container and use only the remote CMDB. Non-containerized deployments are most likely to pass a single file or use ``--config-dir`` to load multiple files. While the implementation would allow mixing files and CMDB, that is not recommended. Implementation details ---------------------- The when ``--config-url`` is handled, ConfigOpt will load the appropriate driver based on the scheme and then call open() to connect to the source. :: def open(self, parsed_url, project, prog): """Open the configuration source. :param parsed_url: Result of parsing the URL given on the command line. :param project: The project value from the ConfigOpt instance. :param prog: The prog value from the ConfigOpt instance. :return: Instance of class derived from ConfigurationSource. """ The ConfigurationSource instance is expected to retain any information it needs to maintain a connection. Whether the connection is long-lived is up to the driver and CMDB implementation. The ConfigurationSource is not explicitly closed. If a connection is lost, it is the responsibility of the driver to re-open it, or emit a hard failure exception. Each time ConfigOpt is asked for the value of an option, it will iterate over its sources and call get(). :: def get(self, group_name, option_name, opt): """Return the value of the option from the group. :param group_name: String name of the group. :param option_name: String name of the option. :param opt: The Opt instance for the option. :return: Option value. :raises: NoValue """ The driver should return the value of the option, if it is present in the database. The return value should either match the type for the Opt, or another type such as a string that can be coerced into the required type. The caller will perform the type conversion in that case. Converting complex types such as lists and dictionaries for storage is left up to the driver to specify, though if the values need to be encoded it would be good if that happened either as JSON or using the same syntax that the INI files use. If the value is not present in the database, the driver should raise NoValue. We can't use None as a sentinal indicating a missing value, so we use a custom exception type instead. The opt parameter is provided in case the driver needs to do advanced coersion (such as mapping an integer value to a choice). It should not be used for type coersion except in special circumstances. The driver is not responsible for handling deprecated option names. The caller will look for a value using the current option name then search again using the deprecated name(s) if no source has a value under the current name. New error classes with more generic names need to be derived from ConfigFilesNotFoundError and ConfigFilesPermissionDeniedError to be used in similar situations by the drivers. A ConfigurationSource subclass for managing the command line options will be created so that option lookup can be standardized. Drivers will be implemented inside the oslo.config library, and loaded through entry points managed by stevedore_ using the namespace ``oslo.config.driver``. .. _stevedore: https://docs.openstack.org/developer/stevedore/ Caching and Mutable Option Handling ----------------------------------- The existing "mutate configuration" behavior, which allows a service to tell oslo.config to reload the configuration file, will be extended to work with the new configuration sources. Values retrieved from the ConfigurationSources may be cached by the ConfigOpt instance to avoid repeated calls to a remote service if the mutable flag for the option is false. Ideally, for CMDB-backed deployments, this means never having to signal to a service to reload its configuration for options that are expected to be changed. When the ConfigOpt class is told to mutate its options, it will discard any cached values it holds, as well as any open ConfigurationSource instances. It will then load its configuration sources again, from scratch. This avoids the need for a cache-flushing API in the ConfigurationSource class, keeping the drivers simple. .. warning:: This is a significant departure from the current behavior, which checks the mutable flags on options and disallows loading new settings when the option is not marked as mutable. This needs to be discussed. Alternatives ------------ We chose to start with etcd because it is widely adopted at sites also using kubernetes. Other CMDB backends, such as consul, zookeeper, and MySQL, can be implemented separately without writing additional specs, unless implementing them will require modifying the API defined for the drivers. A proposal to use confd_ to generate INI files to be read by our services was `also put forward`_. After looking at the capabilities of confd, it is not clear that it supports all of the use cases we have. In particular, cinder's use of dynamically defined option groups for storage backend parameters will make it challenging to generate files. It also appears that confd does not have a loop mechanism, for iterating over all of the configuration groups and options. .. _also put forward: http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-March/114472.html .. _confd: http://www.confd.io There is `another proposal <https://review.openstack.org/130047>`_ that introduces a proxy interface to configuration options. However, it does not provide any mechanism to make it configurable. Impact on Existing APIs ----------------------- There are no changes to the public API for oslo.config. The behavior when oslo.config is told to "mutate" its configuration will change, but the call to perform the mutation is the same. Security impact --------------- We assume that all CMDB access would occur over an encrypted connection. The details of that connnection are left up to the driver (the most common use HTTPS). Credentials for accessing the service need to be provided to each service. These are distributed to the client no differently than other credentials, for accessing the database and message bus, are today. One difference in risk level is that the credentials may make it possible to read all of the other configuration settings from the central CMDB. Performance Impact ------------------ Because configuration options can be registered by a service at any time during operation, it may not always be possible for a CMDB driver initialized early in the process start up to load "all" of the settings in one call. Therefore some configuration accesses may be slower than when reading just from an INI file. We can use caching to mitigate this impact. Drivers are free to implement their own optimizations internally (such as fetching all of the keys in a namespace), but the ability to do so is not assumed in the driver API. Configuration Impact -------------------- ``--config-file`` is changed to ``--config-url``, with the old name continuing to work as a deprecated alias. All of the following forms for specifying configuration files are equivalent. :: --config-file /path/to/file.conf --config-url /path/to/file.conf --config-url file:/path/to/file.conf Deployers using a CMDB will need to load configuration values into their CMDB using a native tool. The scheme for each CMDB must be documented in order for them to be able to do this. For example, the etcd driver will expect a configuration source URL using the form:: etcd://user:password@host:port/unique-client-identifier Within the etcd service, individual configuration options will be organized based on the project, program, configuration group, and option name where the project and program are specified by the service and the group and option names are specified by the code defining the option. For example, the setting to tell the nova (project) conductor (program) the host to use for rabbitmq (oslo_messaging_rabbit.rabbit_host) for the client with identity "myname" (unique-client-identifier) would be stored at:: /myname/nova/conductor/oslo_messaging_rabbit/rabbit_host The "DEFAULT" group will not be treated as special in this regard, so a configuration value "foo" that needs to be set in the DEFAULT group for nova conductor would be stored at:: /myname/nova/conductor/DEFAULT/foo We may want to build a tool to read an INI file and publish it to a CMDB, but that is not part of this spec and would have to be described separately before being implemented. Deployment tools such as Tripleo may provide their mechanism for doing this, or contribute to doing the work through oslo.config to be shared. Developer Impact ---------------- Developers will not notice any difference in their use of oslo.config. Testing Impact -------------- We will need unit tests for choosing the CMDB driver based on the URL scheme. We will need unit tests for the CMDB driver(s). We will need functional tests for the CMDB driver(s). Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: dhellmann EmilienM Milestones ---------- queens-2 Work Items ---------- * Rename ``--config-file`` to ``--config-url``. * Implement the command line argument ConfigurationSource class. * Set up the namespace for entry points for drivers. * Move the existing INI parsing code into a new driver module to be loaded through the namespace. * This may cause a breaking change in the library API, so we may need to retain an import so that the parser is visible through the ``cfg`` module. * Update ConfigOpt to use the ConfigurationSource search algorithm instead of its current search algorithm. * Ensure that ConfigOpt only caches non-mutable values. * Change mutate_config_files() to discard all of the existing data and reload it, without performing any validation. Fix tests and erase dead code left by rewriting that feature. * Write the etcd driver. Incubation ========== None. Adoption -------- TBD Library ------- oslo.config Anticipated API Stabilization ----------------------------- TBD Documentation Impact ==================== TBD Dependencies ============ None References ========== * https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/oslo.config_etcd_backend * https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/tripleo-etcd-transition * https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/oslo-config-pluggable-cmdb * A `related spec`_ by Vladimir Eremin <veremin@mirantis.com> .. _related spec: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/243114/ .. note:: This work is licensed under a `Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License <http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode>`_.

commit_message:
Add ansible and pyton-shade to the base image

Ansible and shade will be used to run some of the provisioning
operations as part of the kubernetes and ansible role based deployment
of the services. Having it in the base images makes it possible to use
any of the service images to run ansible commands, just like we do with
puppet.

Change-Id: I76efb92e27955b6e9054d4e7dcfda5ba1d8b2d2f

subject: Fix KeyError exception in ChanceScheduler.schedule
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-11-01 07:50:15.000000000', 'files': ['neutron_lbaas/tests/unit/drivers/common/test_agent_driver_base.py', 'neutron_lbaas/agent_scheduler.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lbaas/commit/dc1c5f15b7c8e1009de1f937c91e109e3951ac49', 'message': 'Fix KeyError exception in ChanceScheduler.schedule

The return value of function "get_agent_hosting_loadbalancer" is either
None or a dict. Most of the time, it looks good because it usually
returns None. But when multi neutron-server rescheduled the same
loadbalancer from a dead agent almost simultaneously, it might return a
dict, which would cause KeyError since the dict format is such like
{'agent': {'id': xxx, ...}}.

Change-Id: Iac0f99590146ef870a979a6b4ac28b69e9e186e4
Closes-Bug: #1668513
(cherry picked from commit ad7a78197665afc98a1ae4dc5bfabf2019e93241)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix KeyError exception in ChanceScheduler.schedule

The return value of function "get_agent_hosting_loadbalancer" is either
None or a dict. Most of the time, it looks good because it usually
returns None. But when multi neutron-server rescheduled the same
loadbalancer from a dead agent almost simultaneously, it might return a
dict, which would cause KeyError since the dict format is such like
{'agent': {'id': xxx, ...}}.

Change-Id: Iac0f99590146ef870a979a6b4ac28b69e9e186e4
Closes-Bug: #1668513
(cherry picked from commit ad7a78197665afc98a1ae4dc5bfabf2019e93241)

commit_message:
Fix TaskFlow loader to honor engine configuration

The TaskFlow flow loader was not honoring the TaskFlow engine configured in
the octavia.conf. This patch corrects that behavior so the "parallel" engine
can be used.

Change-Id: I4e9a21f1c58cbf65f4247fe3e2255dc614080bc7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/octavia refs/changes/12/518812/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: engine=CONF.task_flow.engine,

commit_message:
Include project_id and user_id in AllocationList.get_all_by_consumer_id

To support including project_id and user_id in the output of GET
/allocations/{consumer_uuid} adjust the
_get_allocations_by_consumer_uuid query to join the necessary tables to
get project_id and user_id information.

Note that this is done as outer joins because in order to support older
(but not much older) microversions we need to allow those fields to be
null.

_get_allocations_by_provider_id is not extended in the same way as we
do not yet have any immediate need for the information in GET
/resource_providers/{uuid}/allocations.

Change-Id: I59175fa51e9553f41c73a6bcd1a77a134e0b19e3
Partially-Implements: bp symmetric-allocations

subject: Fix tempest scenario tests waiters
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-11-12 12:07:24.000000000', 'files': ['neutron_lbaas/tests/tempest/v2/scenario/test_listener_basic.py', 'neutron_lbaas/tests/tempest/v2/scenario/base.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lbaas/commit/2bbf2a1e9f264971095b8ab2d0cf1f5a98ab68ef', 'message': "Fix tempest scenario tests waiters

Cleanups for resources such as listeners, pools and health monitors are
currently using a waiter named _wait_for_load_balancer_status to get an
indication that the cleanup process ended successfully.

Because of the way that waiter is currently used in those cleanups,
it's basically just checking that the load balancer state is:
provisioning_status='ACTIVE'
operating_status='ONLINE'

This is not a good measure for the success of a cleanup for the
aforementioned resources since the deletion process of those simply has
no effect on either loadbalancer provisioning_status or
operating_status. Thus, this is not a good indicator.

This creates issues on high load test deployments.
For example: test_listener_basic is a scenario that deletes a listener
and verifies the absence of the load balancing functionality via
_check_load_balancing_after_deleting_resources.
In case the listener deletion is still undergoing (and currently it
does not have a good indication for that), the load balancer will
accept the traffic and fail the test.

The suggestion solution here is not to use _wait_for_load_balancer_status
as an indicator, but rather add waiters to check specifically if a given
resource got deleted or not.

Change-Id: Ib2e4c60e2db28f1345665c2f5859e8f5fde75bc0
(cherry picked from commit e7f14a6a5ca2472960d7a015b97b4cab580d3f53)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix tempest scenario tests waiters

Cleanups for resources such as listeners, pools and health monitors are
currently using a waiter named _wait_for_load_balancer_status to get an
indication that the cleanup process ended successfully.

Because of the way that waiter is currently used in those cleanups,
it's basically just checking that the load balancer state is:
provisioning_status='ACTIVE'
operating_status='ONLINE'

This is not a good measure for the success of a cleanup for the
aforementioned resources since the deletion process of those simply has
no effect on either loadbalancer provisioning_status or
operating_status. Thus, this is not a good indicator.

This creates issues on high load test deployments.
For example: test_listener_basic is a scenario that deletes a listener
and verifies the absence of the load balancing functionality via
_check_load_balancing_after_deleting_resources.
In case the listener deletion is still undergoing (and currently it
does not have a good indication for that), the load balancer will
accept the traffic and fail the test.

The suggestion solution here is not to use _wait_for_load_balancer_status
as an indicator, but rather add waiters to check specifically if a given
resource got deleted or not.

Change-Id: Ib2e4c60e2db28f1345665c2f5859e8f5fde75bc0
(cherry picked from commit e7f14a6a5ca2472960d7a015b97b4cab580d3f53)

commit_message:
Enable python hash randomization for tests

This should be enabled for all tests to ensure we don't introduce
bugs related to code relying on ordering of unordered types.

Change-Id: I11bcac3c1a5b6999bd82c2c430880cdfb2026593

commit_message:
Remove TLS-specific docker environment

This environment was made for testing, and was only meant to exist while
TLS everywhere got service parity. This is now the case (and has been
since pike was released) so we can safely remove this file.

Change-Id: Ib97cab101ee727ae8d784ecb7847dabdbac3ff17

See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from vitrage.common.constants import VertexProperties as VProps from vitrage.evaluator.actions.recipes.action_steps import EXECUTE_EXTERNAL from vitrage.evaluator.actions.recipes.action_steps import EXECUTION_ENGINE from vitrage.evaluator.actions.recipes import base from vitrage.evaluator.actions.recipes.base import ActionStepWrapper from vitrage.evaluator.template_fields import TemplateFields as TFields NOVA = 'nova' API_CALL = 'api_call' class ExecuteNova(base.Recipe): """Execute a Nova API The 'get_do_recipe' and 'get_undo_recipe' receive action_spec as input. The action_spec contains the following fields: type and properties. example input: action_spec = ActionSpecs('type'= {'execute_nova'}, 'targets'= {target: Vertex}, 'properties' = {api_call : reset-state, parameters: { state: error/active}} """ @staticmethod def get_do_recipe(action_spec): execute_external_step = ExecuteNova._get_execute_external_step( action_spec.targets[TFields.TARGET].get(VProps.ID), action_spec.properties ) return [execute_external_step] @staticmethod def get_undo_recipe(action_spec): execute_external_step = ExecuteNova._get_execute_external_step( action_spec.targets[TFields.TARGET].get(VProps.ID), action_spec.properties ) return [execute_external_step] @staticmethod def _get_execute_external_step(target_id, properties): properties[EXECUTION_ENGINE] = NOVA properties[VProps.ID] = target_id execute_external_step = ActionStepWrapper(EXECUTE_EXTERNAL, properties) return execute_external_step

commit_message:
pluggable notification agent

event, meter (and any other custom pipeline) can be enabled/disabled
by setting `pipelines` option under [notification] agent

Change-Id: Ia21256d0308457d077836e27b45d2acb8bb697e4
Closes-Bug: #1720021

added_lines: from stevedore import namedfrom ceilometer.i18n import _ 'default value is 1.'), cfg.MultiStrOpt('pipelines', default=['meter', 'event'], help="Select which pipeline managers to enable to " " generate data"), def _log_missing_pipeline(self, names): LOG.error(_('Could not load the following pipelines: %s'), names) self.managers = [ext.obj for ext in named.NamedExtensionManager( namespace='ceilometer.notification.pipeline', names=self.conf.notification.pipelines, invoke_on_load=True, on_missing_entrypoints_callback=self._log_missing_pipeline,
